report_title: Prepared Frozen Fish Production Industry Report
executive_summary: The Prepared Frozen Fish Production industry processes fish and seafood into prepared frozen products (including whole dinners, fillets, surimi, soups and chowders). Over the five years to 2021, industry growth has been driven by improvements in the overall economy. In particular, rising disposable income has enabled consumers to purchase more seafood, giving way to rising per capita seafood consumption. However, the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic led to stagnated seafood consumption as a surge in the unemployment rate pressured consumer spending, leading to households opting for less expensive options. Overall, industry revenue is expected to rise at an annualized rate of 2.6% to $9.5 billion over the five years to 2021, including a growth of 2.8% in 2021 alone as the economy recovers from the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Shifting consumer trends have contributed to an increase in demand for seafood, which is often considered a healthier protein option than most poultry and red meat. Over the five years to 2021, per capita seafood consumption increased at an estimated annualized rate of 1.3%. As consumers become busier and have less time to spend on leisure activities, demand for convenient and time-saving products, such as frozen entrees and fish fillets, grows. Thus, frozen foods tend to benefit from busy schedules.

The price of fish and shellfish typically affects the prices industry operators are able to charge their downstream customers once they process the raw inputs. When the price of shellfish rises, the unit-cost price of goods increases, which operators are then able to pass on to consumers in the form of higher prices. Heightened price tags have, in turn, led to an increase in revenue for the average operator. Thus, the rising price of seafood has further boosted revenue growth.

Profitability for the average frozen food producer primarily depends on the price of the operator's respective inputs. The industry has struggled with maintaining a steady flow of fish and shellfish inputs over the past five years. However, long-term volatility in seafood prices has strained profit over the five years to 2021. Additionally, increased operating expenses and lower efficiency during the coronavirus pandemic placed further downward pressure on industry profitability. Nevertheless, the industry ultimately experienced profit expansion, driven by rising demand for seafood, boosting profit (measured as earnings before interest and taxes) from 2.7% of revenue in 2016 to 2.8% in 2021.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for industry products is expected to increase in volume over the five years to 2026. Seafood is typically more expensive than substitute proteins (e.g. red meat and poultry), so consumption of seafood is affected by price from the consumer standpoint. As the US economy strengthens, per capita disposable income is expected to increase, which can increase the appetite for seafood, measured in the amount of seafood consumed per capita.

The prepared frozen fish production industry is expected to experience a slower annualized rate of 1.1% over the five years to 2026, which can benefit industry profit. Nevertheless, continued marketing expenses and other added costs to regain market share is expected to pressure profitability. Consequently, the average industry profit margin, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to decrease marginally to 2.7% in 2026, down from 2.8% in 2021.

Over the five years to 2026, the total value of imports is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 1.0% to $2.2 billion. In 2026 alone, imports are expected to fulfill 18.0% of domestic demand, exhibiting a marginal decline from 2021 levels. The lower labor costs in this industry's top trading partners, typically Asian countries, enables foreign operators to keep prices lower than domestic operators.

industry_definition: This industry processes fish and seafood into prepared products that are then frozen, including whole dinners, fillets, surimi, soups and chowders. Fresh-prepared seafood items are excluded.
key_trends: Shifting consumer trends have contributed to an increase in demand for seafood
Operators invested in new technologies to streamline operations and cut costs
The industry has struggled with maintaining a steady flow of fish and shellfish inputs
The industry is expected to continue focusing on the young professional demographic
Demand for industry products is expected to increase in volume
Despite increasing import competition, exports are forecast to increase
Young professionals that are strapped for time are increasingly purchasing frozen foods for their convenience

market_segmentation.segment_description: Wholesalers are estimated to be the largest downstream market for the Prepared Frozen Fish Production industry.
The second-largest market in this industry is generated from sales to restaurants and food service establishments.
Retailers account for the third-largest downstream market for the industry.
The smallest market for this industry comes from exports.

products_and_services.product_description: Sales of prepared frozen fish represent the largest segment of the Prepared Frozen Fish Production industry's revenue in 2021.
Prepared frozen shellfish products represent the second-largest source of industry sales.
Other prepared frozen seafood products are the third-largest segment in this industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Changes in consumption and price of seafood effect demand for industry products.
Many consumers opt to purchase prepared frozen fish as a result of the convenience that these products offer.
Per capita disposable income largely affects demand for industry products.
Greater health trends also have a significant effect on demand for industry services.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports satisfy just under one-fifth of domestic demand in the Prepared Frozen Fish Production industry.
As the US dollar appreciated over the five years to 2021, US produced goods become relatively more expensive in the international market.

business_locations.location_description: The West region contains the most industry establishments, accounting for 33.5%. Washington and California are the states with the two largest number of establishments within this region, estimated to account for 9.0% and 11.7% respectively.
The Southeast region houses the second-highest number of industry establishments accounting for an estimated 19.5%. The region has a large coastline, best known for its shrimp and crawfish.
Centered around the New England region.
Centered around the Rocky Mountain region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) primarily regulates the Prepared Frozen Fish Production industry.
State and local governments also regulate the industry and are responsible for overseeing food safety within their specific jurisdictions.
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is a federal agency responsible for addressing environmental issues and enforcing environmental protection laws.
The United States implemented country of origin labeling (COOL) on fish and shellfish in September 2006.
Operators in this industry are also subject to antitrust laws, such as the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890 and the Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914.

In 2016, the Port State Measures Agreement was signed into law. This bill enables officials to prohibit foreign vessels suspected of employing illegal fishing processes to receive access to domestic ports and support from port services.
Amid the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, industry operators have had to comply with changing regulations and safety guidelines placed to slow the spread of the virus and protect employee health.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has high revenue volatility.
The industry has high and steady competition.

basis_points.basis_description: Operators compete on price, branding and scale.
Operators face competition from imports and substitutes.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top 4 companies account for 20.6% market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fish and other seafood from the Fishing industry (IBISWorld report 11411) and Fish and Seafood Aquaculture industry (IBISWorld report 11251) represent the most significant purchase costs.
Additionally, producers purchase a significant amount of plastic or cardboard to create safe packaging materials that can effectively preserve the finished product.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital expenditure in this industry is required for machinery that is used to automate the preparing, processing, packaging and freezing procedures during production.
The purchase and maintenance of freezers, preservatives and packaging.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue volatility is primarily caused by fluctuating input costs, consumer tastes and import competition.
Industry revenue volatility is primarily caused by fluctuating input costs, consumer tastes and import competition.
Industry revenue volatility is primarily caused by fluctuating input costs, consumer tastes and import competition.
Furthermore, the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic contributed to additional volatility for the industry as global supply chain disruptions and a weak economic climate weakened demand for seafood.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Operators have pushed to increase the level of automation, by using technology such as collators, conveyor lines and automated case packing equipment.
Furthermore, operators have focused on increasing the efficiency of refrigeration systems, which usually rely on nitrogen or ammonia to preserve the seafood.
Large companies have also aimed to optimize their logistics.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports? How has this changed during the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Imports are the most significant competitive threat to US based companies in the industry. Supply chain disruptions caused by border closures and global shutdowns during COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic have impaired overall trade activity.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Disposable income is a major factor in the fortunes of this industry. Consumers with higher disposable income are typically more likely purchase seafood as it can be relatively more expensive than poultry or pork.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers? How has proximity to suppliers affected access to key inputs during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry strategically locate themselves near major fisheries to minimize shipping costs and to have access to as fresh as possible fish before processing and freezing.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Trends in the price of raw seafood have contributed to revenue volatility in this industry.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: High Liner Foods, a major player in this industry, has recently implemented such an enterprise-wide software system. These systems can maximize efficiency and production capabilities.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years? How have automated processes assisted your company in maintaining production during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry have made investments to further automate their production processes, but greater reliance on machinery requires more skilled and expensive labor.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry must comply with waste disposal regulations from the EPA and local and state regulators.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently? What additional expenses have you incurred as a result of the coronavirus and resulting regulations?
FAQs.answer: As companies in this industry are processing food, they are subject to FDA regulations and oversight. Some companies have had to take on additional expenses to maintain production while limiting the number of employees in facilities at any given time.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: In 2021, average industry profit margins account for an estimated 2.8% of revenue. This represents a slight increase during the five year period, benefiting from continued demand.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months? How has the pandemic affected prices?
FAQs.answer: Market prices of seafood directly impact the material cost of producing prepared frozen fish.

FAQs.question: What quality control processes do you have in place? How do you stay up to date with the latest food safety regulations? What precautions have you taken during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Successful producers in this industry implement effective quality controls to ensure that their products are safe to consume. Tainted frozen fish products can lead to foodborne illnesses and significantly damage a company's image and trustworthiness.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? Do you have any expansion prospects? How have economies of scale aided sales and production during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: The scale and breadth of production largely determine marginal costs and affect the volume that a producer is able to supply, which is a key determinant of market share.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? Have you had any issues securing or keeping contracts? How have you been affected by the pandemic's resulting supply chain disruption?
FAQs.answer: Contracts with raw seafood suppliers reduce supply volatility. Guaranteed supplies at established prices assist in minimizing supply costs and improve production planning. Global shutdowns and border closures severely impaired trade across the manufacturing sector.

FAQs.question: How does the price of seafood affect your business? Do you have fixed, long-term contracts with fisheries? How do you plan to mitigate this threat? How have supply chain disruptions during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic affected seafood prices?
FAQs.answer: The price of fish and seafood is affected by global supply and demand trends. When the price of seafood rises, per-unit costs of finished goods also rises. Operators then pass these higher costs downstream to their customers in the form of higher prices, boosting revenue.

FAQs.question: How does demand for your products correlate with per capita disposable income? How are your products priced?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income is a key determinant of consumer spending. Since many seafood products are sold at higher prices than many other foods, households buy seafood products more often when they have higher levels of disposable income, especially as the price of seafood rises.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in per capita seafood consumption? Which products have been the best sellers over the past five years? Has this shifted during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Generally, when per capita seafood consumption increases, demand for the industry's products should also increase. Demand for seafood stagnated during the pandemic as consumers opted for relatively inexpensive products as substitutes.
